Pikachu (Japanese: \xe3\x83\x94\xe3\x82\xab\xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x82\xa6 Pikachu) is an Electric-type Pok\xc3\xa9mon introduced in Generation I.\n

It evolves from Pichu when leveled up with high friendship and evolves into Raichu when exposed to a Thunder Stone.\n

In Alola, Pikachu evolves into Alolan Raichu when exposed to a Thunder Stone.\n

Pikachu has sixteen other forms that fall into four groups: Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, the partner Pikachu, and Gigantamax Pikachu. Ordinary Pikachu can Gigantamax into Gigantamax Pikachu if it has the Gigantamax Factor. Additionally, many other Pikachu variants have appeared in various media.\n

Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, the partner Pikachu, and Pikachu with the Gigantamax Factor cannot evolve. The initial Pikachu from Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow will refuse to evolve into Raichu unless it is traded and evolved on another save file.\n

Pikachu is popularly known as the mascot of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon franchise and one of Nintendo\'s major mascots. It is also the game mascot of and the player\'s first Pok\xc3\xa9mon in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow and Let\'s Go, Pikachu!, the player\'s first Pok\xc3\xa9mon in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Rumble Blast and Pok\xc3\xa9mon Rumble World, and has made numerous appearances on the covers of spin-off games.\n

Biology

\n

Pikachu is a short, chubby rodent Pok\xc3\xa9mon. It is covered in yellow fur with two horizontal brown stripes on its back. It has a small mouth, long, pointed ears with black tips, and brown eyes. Each cheek is a red circle that contains a pouch for electricity storage. It has short forearms with five fingers on each paw, and its feet each have three toes. At the base of its lightning bolt-shaped tail is a patch of brown fur. A female will have a V-shaped notch at the end of its tail, which looks like the top of a heart. It is classified as a quadruped, but it has been known to stand and walk on its hind legs. Therefore Pikachu is a facultative biped.\n

In the anime, it has been shown that wild Pikachu live in groups in forested areas. Pikachu communicates amongst themselves using squeaks and tail-shaking as friendly gestures. The anime has also shown that Alolan Pikachu are known to greet each other by sniffing one another and rubbing their tails together. Electricity can be used to receive and send messages with each other, as well as other Electric Pok\xc3\xa9mon species. It raises its tail to check its surroundings and is occasionally struck by lightning in this position. When groups grow, they can inadvertently cause lightning storms. Pikachu forage for Berries, which it roasts with electricity to make them tender enough to eat. A sure sign that Pikachu inhabits a location is patches of burnt grass. In the manga, it has been observed eating and sometimes destroying telephone poles, wires, and other electronic equipment. By occasion, it can get unintentionally swallowed by Cramorant. While startled, it looks for ways to escape from the latter.\n

Pikachu charges itself while sleeping overnight, though stress and a lack of sleep can affect this. It can release electric discharges of varying intensity. In the anime, Pikachu has been known to build up energy in its glands, which it will need to discharge to avoid complications. It is also able to release energy through its tail, which acts as a grounding rod, as well as recharge fellow Pikachu with electric shocks. Pikachu and its evolutionary relatives are related to Pachirisu. As shown in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sleep, Pikachu is known to generate electricity through its cheeks while sleeping. Pikachu discharges while sleeping due to it dreaming of firing electric shots.[1]\n

Pikachu and its evolutionary relatives are the only known Pok\xc3\xa9mon capable of learning the move Volt Tackle. Pikachu is also the only known Pok\xc3\xa9mon capable of using the Z-Move Catastropika, and the only known Pok\xc3\xa9mon capable of using the Light Ball item.\n

\n

Forms

\n

Pikachu has sixteen additional forms that fall into four groups: Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, the partner Pikachu, and Gigantamax Pikachu. Additionally, many other Pikachu variants have appeared in various media.\n

\n

Cosplay Pikachu

\n

Cosplay Pikachu is always female, has a black heart-shaped spot at the end of its tail, and can be dressed in any of five outfits corresponding to the five Contest conditions.\n

\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
Cosplay Pikachu\nPikachu Rock Star\nPikachu Belle\nPikachu Pop Star\nPikachu, Ph.D\nPikachu Libre\n
\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

Pikachu in a cap

\n

Pikachu in a cap is always male and has eight variants, each wearing one of Ash\'s hats from the anime. Pikachu in a cap is the only known Pok\xc3\xa9mon capable of using the Z-Move 10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt. Pikachu in a Cap cannot use Catastropika or Gigantamax.\n

Partner Pikachu

\n

The partner Pikachu is the Pok\xc3\xa9mon the player starts with in Pok\xc3\xa9mon: Let\'s Go, Pikachu!. This Pikachu can be either gender. It has has higher base stats than normal Pikachu. Unlike other Pikachu, the partner Pikachu can learn the exclusive moves Zippy Zap, Floaty Fall, and Splishy Splash, as well as having access to the partner power Pika Papow.\n

The partner Pikachu is not differentiated from standard Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon: Let\'s Go, Pikachu! and Let\'s Go, Eevee!\'s Pok\xc3\xa9dex, and it cannot be transferred out of the games.\n

\n\n\n\n\n
Partner Pikachu\n
\n
\n


\n

\n

Gigantamax Pikachu

\n

As Gigantamax Pikachu, it becomes larger and chubbier. Its tail becomes longer and becomes capable of storing all of the electricity it generates, causing it to glow a bright yellow and enabling it to become as powerful as a lightning strike. Three red clouds float around the tail. Its power is equal to that of a power plant; however, it is difficult to use it in peoples\' homes since Pikachu can only remain in its Gigantamax form for a short time.[2] Gigantamax Pikachu is the only known Pok\xc3\xa9mon capable of using the G-Max Move G-Max Volt Crash.\n

\n\n\n\n\n
Gigantamax Pikachu\n
\n
\n

Evolution

\n

Pikachu evolves from Pichu and evolves into Raichu.\n

In Alola, it evolves into Alolan Raichu.\n

Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, Partner Pikachu, and Pikachu with the Gigantamax Factor cannot evolve.\n

(For specifics on this Pok\xc3\xa9mon\'s evolution in the games, refer to Game data→Evolution data.)\n

In the anime

\n

Main series

\n
Pikachu in the anime
\n

Major appearances

\n
Ash\'s Pikachu
\n

Ash has a Pikachu that he obtained from Professor Oak in Pok\xc3\xa9mon - I Choose You!, the first episode of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon anime, which also marked its debut. He was the signature Pok\xc3\xa9mon of the anime series from the original series to Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journeys: The Series and appeared in almost every non-special episode and every Pok\xc3\xa9mon movie released throughout that point. In The Climb to Be the Very Best!, he was revealed to be capable of Gigantamaxing. He always remains outside of his Pok\xc3\xa9 Ball.\n

\n
Pikachutwo
\n

In Mewtwo Strikes Back, Mewtwo cloned Ash\'s Pikachu. This Pikachu can be distinguished from Ash\'s due to the spikes in the black marks found on the tips of its ears. It is also comparatively more aggressive than Ash\'s Pikachu and slurs its speech, defects possibly caused by Ash tampering with Mewtwo\'s cloning machine during the cloning process. It reappeared in the sequel special Mewtwo Returns and the remake movie Mewtwo Strikes Back\xe2\x80\x94Evolution.\n

\n
Puka
\n

A Pikachu nicknamed Puka was owned by Victor on Seafoam Island in The Pi-Kahuna. This blue-eyed Pikachu saved Ash from drowning by having the ability to sense tidal waves approaching.\n

\n
Sparky
\n

Ritchie has a Pikachu nicknamed Sparky, who debuted in A Friend In Deed. Sparky, unlike most Pikachu, has a tuft of fur on the top of its head, and, unlike Ash\'s Pikachu, has no problem with living inside a Pok\xc3\xa9 Ball.\n

\n
Ashachu
\n

Ash was turned into a Pikachu in Hocus Pok\xc3\xa9mon by a Pok\xc3\xa9mon magician named Lily. He reverted to his human form at the beginning of the next episode.\n

\n
Cosplay Pikachu
\n

All of the Cosplay Pikachu appeared in Lights! Camera! Pika!, under the ownership of Frank. They reappeared in Hoopa and the Clash of Ages, where they were all summoned by Hoopa as part of a prank on Ash and his Pikachu.\n

\n
Ash\'s Pikachu (M20)
\n

The Ash Ketchum of the alternate continuity introduced in I Choose You! has a Pikachu of his own. Like the Pikachu of the main series, this Pikachu was his first Pok\xc3\xa9mon and his main partner, almost always remaining outside of his Pok\xc3\xa9 Ball.\n

\n
Goh\'s Pikachu
\n

Goh caught a Pikachu in Gotta Catch a What?!. She, along with a few others of her kind, later evolved into Raichu during the episode.\n

\n
Captain Pikachu
\n

In The Pendant That Starts It All: Part Two, a Pikachu nicknamed Captain Pikachu appeared under the ownership of Friede.\n

\n
Other
\n

In Pikachu\'s Goodbye, many wild Pikachu appear and Ash\'s Pikachu wants to play with them. Eventually, Ash tries to release him thinking it\'d be best for Pikachu to be with his own kind, but he refused to leave Ash\'s side.\n

In The Ultimate Test, James used a Pikachu in the Pok\xc3\xa9mon League Admissions Exam, but it was defeated by the instructor\'s Graveler. After interfering with a battle Ash was having with the instructor, James later tried to steal this Pikachu, only for it to zap James instead, as instructed by its instructor.\n

In Pok\xc3\xa9mon Mystery Dungeon: Team Go-Getters Out of the Gate!, a Pikachu was kidnapped by a Skarmory. As a result, Team Go-Getters set out to rescue him as their first mission. Pikachu provided them with some items in the battle.\n

In BWS01, Ayumi\'s female Pikachu was trained on how to properly use Thunderbolt with the help of Cilan and Stunfisk.\n

A Mirror World Pikachu appeared in The Cave of Mirrors!, under the ownership of Mirror Ash. Unlike his regular world counterpart, Mirror Pikachu is a mischievous roughneck.\n

In Lights! Camera! Pika!, Frank has multiple Pikachu that would participate in his filmmaking endeavors.\n

In Hoopa and the Clash of Ages, multiple Pikachu were summoned by Hoopa as part of a prank on Ash and his Pikachu, though the prank failed. They were then returned to their original locations with the help of Ash\'s Pikachu, who coordinated them into Hoopa\'s portals.\n

In Battling at Full Volume!, Jimmy\'s Pikachu, nicknamed Spike, was used in a battle against Ash\'s Pikachu. Since Ash was ill, Serena took his place, unbeknownst to Jimmy and Spike. However, the match was interrupted by Team Rocket, who captured Spike, but Spike was promptly saved.\n

In A Plethora of Pikachu!, Pikala has multiple Pikachu. One of them was nicknamed Curly, while another that is Shiny was nicknamed the Boss. The Boss reappeared in a flashback in Beauty is Only Crystal Deep!. In Battle Royal 151!, another one of Pikala\'s Pikachu, nicknamed Bolt, competed in the Battle Royal round of the Manalo Conference. It defeated a Magikarp and Pyukumuku, but ended up losing to Jessie\'s Mimikyu.\n

Multiple Pikachu appeared in Gotta Catch a What?!. Several of them evolved into Raichu using the Thunder Stones they dug up.\n

A Pikachu owned by Alternate World Ash appeared in Showdown at the Gates of Warp!.\n

\n

Minor appearances

\n

In Pok\xc3\xa9mon Emergency!, Nurse Joy has multiple Pikachu, all of whom helped Ash\'s own Pikachu defeat Team Rocket and send them blasting off for the first time. They reappeared in a flashback in Pikachu\'s Goodbye.\n

Multiple Pikachu appeared in Battle Aboard the St. Anne.\n

In a flashback in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Double Trouble, Travis\'s mother Luana temporarily mistook Ash for Travis when she saw Pikachu on Ash\'s shoulder, since Travis has a Pikachu of his own.\n

A Pikachu appeared in Brock\'s demonstration in A Bite to Remember, where it evolved into a Raichu.\n

In Lights, Camerupt, Action!, a Pikachu appeared in two of Elijah\'s movies. Red\'s Pikachu was featured in a film that Ash and Gary were watching when they were younger. In a different movie that Ash and his friends were watching at the time the episode was taking place, another Pikachu helped Plusle and Minun on their mission to rescue Princess Kirlia from the evil Exploud.\n

In Lucario and the Mystery of Mew, a Pikachu was one of Mew\'s transformations.\n

In Cooking up a Sweet Story!, Abigail\'s Pikachu, nicknamed Sugar, went missing prior to the events of the episode. As a result, Ash\'s Pikachu had to fill in for it so that its owner would have the confidence to win a cooking competition. At the end of the episode, Sugar returned, whereupon it was revealed to have evolved into a Raichu.\n

A Pikachu appeared in flashbacks in The Keystone Pops!, under the ownership of an Aura Guardian.\n

Volkner\'s Raichu was seen as a Pikachu during flashbacks of his childhood in Flint Sparks the Fire!.\n

A Pikachu appeared in Clemont\'s demonstration in To Catch a Pok\xc3\xa9mon Smuggler!, where it evolved into a Raichu using a Thunder Stone.\n

A Pikachu appeared in Diancie and the Cocoon of Destruction, under the ownership of Uschi.\n

A Pikachu appeared in a fantasy in Now You See Them, Now You Don\'t!.\n

A Pikachu appeared in a fantasy in Showering the World with Love!.\n

In Securing the Future!, a Trainer\'s Pikachu joined the rest of Alola in showering Necrozma with light so it could return to its normal form.\n

In Battle Royal 151!, a Trainer\'s Pikachu competed in the Battle Royal preliminary round of the Manalo Conference but ended up losing.\n

Multiple Pikachu appeared in Distant Blue Sky!.\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon Evolutions

\n
Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Evolutions
\n

In The Champion, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Victor and Gloria appeared in Wyndon Stadium, cheering on the battle between Victor and Leon.\n

In The Eclipse, a Pikachu was briefly seen in a flashback, frozen in Lusamine\'s trophy room. Additionally, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Elio and Selene appeared playing with some children.\n

In The Visionary, two Pikachu wearing the hats and glasses of Calem and Serena appeared near Lysandre and Diantha while they were having a conversation.\n

In The Plan, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Hilbert and Hilda appeared under the ownership of a Trainer who was listening to Ghetsis\'s speech in Accumula Town.\n

In The Rival, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Lucas and Dawn appeared in the reception hall of the Battle Tower.\n

In The Wish, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Brendan and May appeared in Pacifidlog Town, watching the battle between May\'s Mega Rayquaza and Zinnia\'s Mega Salamence.\n

In The Show, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Ethan and Lyra briefly appeared under the ownership of Trainers watching the Kimono Girls\' performance in Ecruteak City.\n

In The Discovery, a female partner Pikachu appeared under the ownership of Elaine. She used her in a battle against Green and her Clefable and won in one hit. Additionally, two Pikachu wearing the hats of Chase and Elaine appeared in Pallet Town.\n

In the manga

\n
Pikachu in The Electric Tale of Pikachu
\n

Ash & Pikachu

\n
Main article: Ash\'s Pikachu
\n

Ash\'s Pikachu is a starring character in Ash & Pikachu, a manga adaptation of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon anime based on Ash\'s adventures in Johto, Hoenn, and Battle Frontier.\n

\n

The Electric Tale of Pikachu

\n
Main article: Ash\'s Pikachu (EToP)
\n

Ash\'s Pikachu is a main character in The Electric Tale of Pikachu, an adaptation of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon anime. Ash discovered it under the floorboards at his home, where it was chewing on wires to eat the electricity. After catching it, Ash decided to make it his first Pok\xc3\xa9mon.\n

Sparky, Ritchie\'s Pikachu, first appeared in Welcome to the Big Leagues. In this manga, its nickname is translated as "Chuchino".\n

Magical Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journey and Pok\xc3\xa9mon Chamo-Chamo \xe2\x98\x86 Pretty \xe2\x99\xaa

\n
Main article: Pikachu (MPJ)
\n

Pikachu is a main character in Magical Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journey. He is the first Pok\xc3\xa9mon befriended by Hazel, debuting in How Do You Do, Pikachu?. Pikachu is one of the few Pok\xc3\xa9mon in Magical Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journey that cannot speak human language, although the others seem to understand him. He is described as rather scatterbrained at times. Pikachu returns as a main character in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Chamo-Chamo \xe2\x98\x86 Pretty \xe2\x99\xaa, the sequel to the Magical Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journey series.\n

Ash\'s Pikachu also makes a cameo appearance in bonus chapters at the end of every volume of the Magical Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journey manga.\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon Adventures

\n
Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Adventures
\n

Red, Green & Blue arc

\n
Main article: Pika
\n

Pikachu debuted in Wanted: Pikachu!, where it was stealing food in Pewter City. The townsfolk kept chasing him around, but ended up getting shocked by him. Red arrived and caught him, ending the chaos. Although extremely disobedient at first, even prone to regularly electrocuting his owner, the two eventually got over this enmity, and this Pikachu, nicknamed "Pika", became one of his most loyal and trusted fighters, being used in almost every major battle Red has had.\n

A Pikachu appeared as a silhouette when Green talked about Mew in The Jynx Jinx.\n

In Just a Spearow Carrier, a Pikachu appeared with its Trainer at Indigo Plateau. It noticeably had a flower by its ear.\n

\n

Yellow arc

\n

Pika served on Yellow\'s team while Red missing during this chapter, before being returned to him. During his time with Yellow, Pika learned how to Surf.\n

A Pikachu appeared in The Kindest Tentacruel as one of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon in Yellow\'s fantasy about evolution via Evolution stone.\n

A Pikachu appeared in Can You Diglett? as a silhouette when Agatha and Lorelei explained to Red about how Pok\xc3\xa9mon and people can\'t coexist with each other.\n

\n

Gold, Silver & Crystal arc

\n
Main article: Chuchu
\n

A Pikachu appeared in a fantasy of Professor Elm\'s explanation of Pok\xc3\xa9mon Eggs in Teddiursa\'s Picnic.\n

A Pikachu appeared in Ursaring Major in a fantasy of Silver when he explained the vital points of Pok\xc3\xa9mon.\n

In Tyranitar War, Yellow was revealed to have obtained her own Pikachu, nicknamed "Chuchu". While staying at the Pok\xc3\xa9mon Day-Care with Pika, the two Pikachu ended up producing an Egg, which later hatched into Gold\'s Pichu, Pibu.\n

Two Pikachu owned by a pair of Pok\xc3\xa9 Fans appeared in Oh, It\'s Ho-Oh!, going towards Indigo Plateau.\n

\n

Diamond & Pearl arc

\n

A Pikachu appeared in Suffering Psyduck.\n

\n

X & Y arc

\n

Multiple Pikachu were among the Electric-type Pok\xc3\xa9mon that charged the Prism Tower during a blackout in Pangoro Poses a Problem.\n

\n

Omega Ruby & Alpha Sapphire arc

\n
Main article: Cosplay Pikachu
\n

Five Pikachu appeared in Salamence Evolves, where they each wear the five costumes available for the Cosplay Pikachu: Pikachu Rock Star, Pikachu Belle, Pikachu Pop Star, Pikachu Ph.D., and Pikachu Libre. Lisia revealed to Chaz that Ruby created the concept of Pok\xc3\xa9mon wearing costumes for Contests. Noticeably, some of these Cosplay Pikachu were male. They reappeared in a flashback in PS603.\n

\n

Sun, Moon, Ultra Sun & Ultra Moon arc

\n

A Trainer\'s Pikachu appeared in The Decision and the Tournament of Six.\n

Hau\'s Pichu evolved into Pikachu prior to Shock!! Father in the Pendant!.\n

\n

Sword & Shield arc

\n

A Pikachu appeared in Gulp Gulp!! Pok\xc3\xa9mon, having been swallowed by a Cramorant. It reappeared in PASS40 and PASS41, where it had Gigantamaxed due to the Darkest Day.\n

\n

Scarlet & Violet arc

\n

A female Pikachu appeared in Scarlet & Violet arc under Scarlet\'s ownership. She was shown to be able to Terastallize into a Flying type.\n

Manga\nChapter\nEntry\n
Pok\xc3\xa9mon Adventures\nPS004\nWhen several of these Pok\xc3\xa9mon gather, their electricity could build up and cause lightning storms. Forest dwellers, they are few in number and exceptionally rare. The pouches in their cheeks discharge electricity at their opponents. The Pikachu are believed to be highly intelligent.\n

Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pocket Monsters
\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pocket Monsters

\n
Main article: Red\'s Pikachu (Pocket Monsters)
\n

Pikachu is one of the main characters in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pocket Monsters and its sequels. It was the second Pok\xc3\xa9mon that Red caught on his own, but the first he kept.\n

Pikachu is one of the few Pok\xc3\xa9mon in the manga that cannot speak human language. He is the cousin of Clefairy and is considered the smarter of the two.\n

In Clefairy Evolves... At Last?!, Pikachu evolved into Raichu, but he has since devolved back to the Pikachu stage.\n

Yellow has a Pikachu of his own, which debuted in The Fake Pikachu!!.\n

\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon Ranger the Comic: Double Mission

\n

A Pikachu appeared in a fantasy in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Ranger the Comic: Double Mission Episode One.\n

\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon Zensho

\n

Satoshi caught a Pikachu in PZ02. It later evolved into a Raichu in PZ10.\n
\n

\n

In the TCG

\n
Pikachu in the TCG
\n
Pikachu TCG Coin
\n
Main article: Pikachu (TCG)
\n

Pikachu manages to find its way into many of the expansions, causing there to be 211 known non-reprint Pok\xc3\xa9mon cards featuring Pikachu. There are also various Trainer cards with Pikachu in the card\'s artwork too, including the very sought-after tournament promos such as No.1 Trainer.\n

The first Pikachu that appeared in the TCG was Pikachu in the Base Set (which was reprinted in Base Set 2 and in POP Series 2 with different artwork). It was followed in the next set by another Pikachu (which was also reprinted in the Legendary Collection). The third Pikachu card released was the first-ever English promo card, Pikachu. The original Base Set Pikachu was also released as a special promotional card at E3.\n

In the early days of the TCG, several notable errors were made regarding the Pikachu cards. The Base Set Pikachu was released with altered artwork at first, depicting it with red cheeks, instead of the original yellow. While this matched Ken Sugimori\'s artwork, the yellow color on its cheeks was intentional by the artist, who depicted Pikachu using ThunderShock. This error appeared in both the E3 promotional version and the normal Base Set release. A second error was made in the production of Jungle set booster packs, which, instead of the Jungle set\'s Pikachu, sometimes contained first edition versions of the Pikachu that was released as a promo card.\n

Pikachu has also been featured on a number of TCG coins, with one being included with the English and European languages-only Base Set 2. This coin was also featured in the Pok\xc3\xa9mon Play It! PC game. A Pikachu coin is also featured in the Game Boy game Pok\xc3\xa9mon Trading Card Game, and is one of the coins that can be obtained in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Trading Card Game 2: The Invasion of Team GR!, where it is given by Isaac to winners of the Lightning Club.\n

\n

Two Pikachu figures have been released.\n

Other appearances

\n
Pikachu in Pokk\xc3\xa9n Tournament
\n

Pokk\xc3\xa9n Tournament

\n
Main article: Pikachu (Pokk\xc3\xa9n)
\n
Main article: Pikachu Libre (Pokk\xc3\xa9n)
\n

Pikachu is a playable character for the arcade fighting game. His moveset includes electrical attacks the species uses in the main games, like Thunderbolt, Electro Ball, and Thunder. In Burst form, he can use the Burst Attack Volt Shock Fist. Several of his attacks and victory poses are directly taken from Heihachi and Kazuya Mishima\'s movesets from the Tekken series.\n

Pikachu overwhelms opponents with powerful electric shocks and quick movements.[3]\n

Pikachu Libre was first announced alongside the Wii U port of the game. She was later released as an additional fighter on the original arcade version.\n

Pikachu Libre, a wrestling idol, is a small masked fighter overflowing with fighting spirit.\n

\n

Super Smash Bros.

\n
Main article: Pikachu (Super Smash Bros.)
\n

Detective Pikachu

\n

Detective Pikachu stars a Pikachu that is capable of speaking the human language, but only the player character Tim Goodman is capable of hearing him. Much like Meowth from the anime, he is incapable of using moves that most Pikachu are capable of using. This Pikachu also really loves to drink coffee. Early on in the game, a regular Pikachu also briefly appears.\n

\n
Pikachu and Eliana in the Lightning Force music video
\n
Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon UNITE
\n

Lightning Force

\n

The Brazilian music video Lightning Force features a stop motion animated Pikachu. This Pikachu is also shown later as a live action actor with a full-body costume.\n

\n

Pikachu is playable through obtaining a Unite License. It is a ranged attacker.\n

Game data

\n

As the player

\n
Main article: Pikachu (Pok\xc3\xa9Park)
\n

Pikachu appears as the player character in both Pok\xc3\xa9Park Wii: Pikachu\'s Adventure and its sequel, Pok\xc3\xa9Park 2: Wonders Beyond. He falls down a mysterious tunnel one day with his friends Charmander, Chikorita, and Piplup and ends up in the Pok\xc3\xa9Park. There he goes on a quest to save the Pok\xc3\xa9Park from certain destruction. He later travels to a new Pok\xc3\xa9Park which is being threatened by the ever-expanding Wish Park. At the new Pok\xc3\xa9Park he meets Snivy, Tepig, and Oshawott, and they help to save the Pok\xc3\xa9Park from danger.\n

\n

NPC appearances

\n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Stadium: Pikachu stars in the mini-game "Thundering Dynamo" alongside Voltorb. This mini-game involves charging up electric power.
    • \n
  • Hey You, Pikachu!: Pikachu stars alongside an unnamed child (who bears a striking resemblance to Red) who was recently taught how to interact with wild Pok\xc3\xa9mon by Professor Oak. The boy and Pikachu form a bond and go on many adventures together, and one day the Pikachu decides to live with the boy.
    • \n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Stadium 2: Pikachu can be used in "Pichu\'s Power Plant" if one is detected in a Transferred Pok\xc3\xa9mon game.
    • \n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball: Pikachu serves as a Ball-Saver, but it will only work if the Lightning Meter is full.
    • \n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball: Ruby & Sapphire: Pikachu has the same role as in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball but is sometimes helped by Pichu. Pikachu also appears on the Catch \'Em Mode banner.
    • \n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Channel: Much like Hey You, Pikachu!, Pok\xc3\xa9mon Channel focuses on a boy and a Pikachu bonding through social interactions, such as going outside and talking to other Pok\xc3\xa9mon, and watching TV together.

Held items

\n

Pok\xc3\xa9mon caught in Generation I must be traded to a Generation II game in order for a held item to appear. In Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow, the player gets the Light Ball by trading a initial Pikachu, otherwise the Pikachu will be holding a Berry. In Pok\xc3\xa9walker, only Pikachu found in Yellow Forest are carrying items.\n

Form data

\n

Pikachu has sixteen additional forms that fall into four groups: Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, the partner Pikachu, and Gigantamax Pikachu. All forms except the partner Pikachu are recognized by an in-game Pok\xc3\xa9dex; partner Pikachu has only been named in promotional materials.[4]\n

\n

Cosplay Pikachu

\n

Cosplay Pikachu is the base form of a group of six interchangeable forms exclusive to Pok\xc3\xa9mon Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire. It is a female Pikachu who has a black, heart-shaped mark at the end of its tail, obtained from a Pok\xc3\xa9mon Breeder after the player takes part in their first Pok\xc3\xa9mon Contest Spectacular. Cosplay Pikachu can change forms by dressing up in different costumes corresponding to each of the five contest conditions (Coolness, Beauty, Cuteness, Cleverness, and Toughness); each form also automatically learns a move that Pikachu otherwise could not learn. Cosplay Pikachu can change or remove its costume at any Contest Hall, forgetting the move it learned with the last costume (if it still knows it) and learning the move from the new costume (if applicable). If Cosplay Pikachu removes its costume while the only move it knows is the move tied to its costume, it learns Thunder Shock.\n

Unlike other Pikachu, Cosplay Pikachu cannot evolve or breed. It also cannot be traded via the GTS or Wonder Trade. Additionally, as it is not present in any games besides Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire, Cosplay Pikachu cannot be deposited into Pok\xc3\xa9mon Bank, and it does not register as a separate form in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Bank\'s Pok\xc3\xa9dex, despite it registering separately in the Pok\xc3\xa9dex of Omega Ruby and Alpha Sapphire.\n

Pikachu in a cap

\n

Pikachu in a cap are eight event-exclusive, non-interchangeable forms of Pikachu that debuted in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sun and Moon. Like Ash\'s Pikachu, these Pikachu are always male, and they cannot evolve or breed. They are also able to use the event-exclusive Z-Crystal Pikashunium Z and its corresponding Z-Move 10,000,000 Volt Thunderbolt. Their cries differ from that of regular Pikachu.\n

Six variants exist in Sun and Moon, one for each of Ash\'s hats from the anime\'s original series to Pok\xc3\xa9mon the Series: Sun & Moon. A seventh variant debuted in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon, wearing the Partner Cap, Ash\'s hat from Pok\xc3\xa9mon the Movie: I Choose You!. An eighth variant debuted in the Version 1.2.0 update of Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sword and Shield, wearing the World Cap, Ash\'s hat from Pok\xc3\xa9mon Journeys: The Series.\n

The original six Pikachu in a cap were distributed via serial codes in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sun and Moon in celebration of the Pok\xc3\xa9mon anime\'s 20th movie, and by extension, the anime\'s 20th anniversary. Partner Cap Pikachu was distributed in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Ultra Sun and Ultra Moon via a QR Code that can be scanned. All eight Pikachu in a cap (including World Cap Pikachu) were distributed via serial codes in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sword and Shield to commemorate the anime\'s timeslot change to Fridays in Japan; uniquely, the Pikachu from this distribution can learn Volt Tackle from the Move Reminder, Jack.\n

Partner Pikachu

\n

The partner Pikachu has a separate internal index from standard Pikachu. This allows it to have higher base stats than wild Pikachu.\n

The partner Pikachu is not differentiated from standard Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon: Let\'s Go, Pikachu! and Let\'s Go, Eevee!\'s Pok\xc3\xa9dex, and it cannot be transferred out of the games.\n

Gigantamax

\n

Gigantamax Pikachu can only be obtained through special methods, and the Gigantamax Factor cannot be bred.\n

Evolution data

\n

Cosplay Pikachu, Pikachu in a cap, the partner Pikachu, and Pikachu with the Gigantamax Factor cannot evolve. The initial Pikachu from Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow will refuse to evolve into Raichu unless it is traded and evolved on another save file.\n

Trivia

\n
$1 coin from Niue featuring Pikachu
\n
Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Stadium
\n
Pikachu in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Battle Chess
\n
  • Pikachu was designed by Atsuko Nishida.[5][6]\n
    • Gigantamax Pikachu was designed by James Turner.[7]
    • \n
  • Pikachu originally had a short, stout design during the initial release of Pok\xc3\xa9mon Red and Green, but its design was altered for the anime and subsequent entries of the games, becoming slightly taller and skinnier. According to Ken Sugimori, Pikachu\'s design was altered to make animating its actions easier.[6]\n
    • Its Gigantamax form is a reference to its original rotund appearance.[8]
    • \n
  • The nation of Niue released a one-dollar coin with its coat of arms on one side and Pikachu on the other to promote the Pok\xc3\xa9mon franchise.
    • \n
  • Pikachu and its evolved form both share their category with Rattata, Raticate, Sandshrew, Sandslash, Pawmi, and Pawmo. They are all known as the Mouse Pok\xc3\xa9mon, though Rattata and Raticate were originally called the Rat Pok\xc3\xa9mon prior to Generation III.
    • \n
  • Veronica Taylor has said Pikachu is her favorite Pok\xc3\xa9mon. Sarah Natochenny has as well, shared with Mew.
    • \n
  • Pikachu has served as the inspiration for the naming of several scientific discoveries:\n
    • In 2008, Japanese researchers discovered a new protein that helps carry electrical impulses from the eyes to the brain and named it pikachurin. According to them, it was so named for sharing Pikachu\'s "lightning-fast moves and shocking electric effects".
      • \n
    • The springtail species Dicranocentrus pikachu was named after Pikachu.[9]
      • \n
    • The spider species Epicratinus pikachu was named after Pikachu due to the female spider\'s epigynum resembling its face.[10]
      • \n
    • The spider species Alistra pikachu was named after Pikachu due to its yellow coloration.[11]
      • \n
    • The beetle species Hiperantha pikachu was named after Pikachu because of its yellow elytra with a black apical band that resembles Pikachu\'s ears.[12]
    • \n
  • Macy\'s Thanksgiving Day Parade has included three Pikachu balloons. "Flying Pikachu" was the first, flown from 2001 to 2005, and was used in a morning rush hour test of wind conditions in Times Square after an accident involving an M&M\'s balloon in the 2005 parade.[13] It was last used in the August 2006 Party of the Decade in New York City\'s Bryant Park. The second balloon debuted in the 2006 parade, features glowing cheeks, and chases a Pok\xc3\xa9 Ball balloon. The third, introduced in the 2014 parade, wears a green scarf and holds a small, Pikachu-shaped snowman.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon that serves as the player\'s first Pok\xc3\xa9mon in the core series games that has a pre-evolved form. However, Pichu (its pre-evolved form) does not exist in either game in which it it fills this role.
    • \n
  • According to A Sneak Peek at Pok\xc3\xa9mon, Pikachu can deliver a constant current of 1000 amperes.
    • \n
  • Pikachu has the most event-exclusive moves available to it.\n
    • Additionally, Pikachu is the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon with two exclusive Z-Moves.
    • \n
  • When starting a new game in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow, Pikachu\'s front sprite appears with a slightly different color palette (the palette index number 0x10) than usual when it is introduced by Professor Oak. This is the same red/yellow palette used for Mew, Mewtwo, and Jynx (except the Virtual Console Jynx), as well as the battle sprites of all Pok\xc3\xa9mon Trainers.\n
    • Due to the color palette used at the start of Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow, Pikachu has red cheeks (in the Game Boy Color) or pink cheeks (in the Super Game Boy). However, in this game\'s normal gameplay, Pikachu has dark orange cheeks instead.
    • \n
  • In the Japanese Pok\xc3\xa9mon Stadium, Pikachu is the only usable Pok\xc3\xa9mon that is not fully evolved.
    • \n
  • In Pok\xc3\xa9mon Yellow and from Generation VI to Brilliant Diamond and Shining Pearl, Pikachu uses its cry from the anime (voiced by Ikue Otani). Before Let\'s Go, Pikachu! and Let\'s Go, Eevee!, it was the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon to do so in core series games.\n
    • Its battle cry differs from status or Pok\xc3\xa9dex screens.
      • \n
    • The initial Pikachu in Yellow has unique voice clips in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Stadium and Stadium 2.
      • \n
    • In Pok\xc3\xa9mon Legends: Arceus and Pok\xc3\xa9mon Scarlet and Violet, it uses an updated version of its original cry, like other Pok\xc3\xa9mon.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon that serves as the player\'s first Pok\xc3\xa9mon in a core series game that does not have a 7:1 gender ratio.
    • \n
  • Pok\xc3\xa9mon Black, White, Black 2, and White 2 are the only core series games in which Pikachu cannot be obtained without transporting or through an event.
    • \n
  • Pikachu was the focus of the Sleeping Pikachu Collection at the Pok\xc3\xa9mon Center in June 2014.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is the only not fully-evolved Pok\xc3\xa9mon whose base stats increased in Generation VI as well as the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon to receive more than one stat increase: Defense and Special Defense.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is the only Pok\xc3\xa9mon that can be caught in all three pinball titles: Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball, Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball mini, and Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pinball: Ruby & Sapphire.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is the 25th Pok\xc3\xa9mon in both the National Pok\xc3\xa9dex and Alola Pok\xc3\xa9dex in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Sun and Moon.
    • \n
  • Pikachu originally had a second-stage evolution named "Gorochu" (Japanese: \xe3\x82\xb4\xe3\x83\xad\xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x82\xa6 Goroch\xc5\xab), which would have had two horns and fangs.[14][15] Sugimori stated that while there was nothing wrong with its appearance, it was nonetheless omitted from Pok\xc3\xa9mon Red and Green, as the staff found that the game balance was better without it, and the limited game space meant that some Pok\xc3\xa9mon originally designed to evolve twice were changed to evolve only once.[6]
    • \n
  • Pikachu appears in Pok\xc3\xa9mon Battle Chess. It doesn\'t behave like any traditional piece in chess but behaves like a gold general in shogi.
    • \n
  • Pikachu has been depicted to have a white belly similar to its evolved form Raichu in the Pocket Monsters Carddass Trading Cards as seen here.
    • \n
  • Pikachu is currently represented in the Trading Card Game by more cards than any other Pok\xc3\xa9mon, with 211 unique cards.
    • \n
  • On December 11, 2023, Google revealed that Pikachu was the "most searched Pok\xc3\xa9mon" in the platform\'s history during its 25 years of creation.[16][17]
\n

Origin

\n

Pikachu\'s designer, Atsuko Nishida, revealed in an interview that this Pok\xc3\xa9mon was originally a daifuku-like creature with ears sticking out. Its black ear tips are remnants of this original concept.[6][15]\n

Nishida named the Pok\xc3\xa9mon Pikachu "without giving it much thought", and while it wasn\'t originally intended to be based on a mouse, Game Freak CEO Satoshi Tajiri made the decision to base it on such. During the process of making Pikachu "cuter", as per the instructions of game designer K\xc5\x8dji Nishino, Nishida added cheek pouches for it to store electricity in. These were inspired by squirrels, which store food in their cheeks. Pikachu\'s yellow colouration and lightning bolt-shaped tail were given to express Pikachu\'s electrical attributes and make its type easier to recognise and understand. According to Nishida, Pikachu\'s stripes aren\'t based on anything in particular, and were added to fill the empty space on Pikachu\'s back, as it is always visible during battle.[6][15]\n

Pikachu\'s Gigantamax form is a reference to its earlier, more rotund design from Generations I and II.[8]\n

\n

Name origin

\n

Pikachu is a combination of \xe3\x83\x94\xe3\x82\xab\xe3\x83\x94\xe3\x82\xab pikapika (onomatopoeia for sparkle) and \xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc\xe3\x83\x81\xe3\x83\xa5\xe3\x83\xbc ch\xc5\xabch\xc5\xab (the sound of a mouse squeaking).[6][18]\n
